code:
# @param {Integer} x
# @param {Integer} y
# @param {Integer} z
# @return {Integer}
def longest_string(x, y, z)
  # Starting with "AA" and "BB" strings, we can have at most 2 in a row for each
  # "AB" strings can be inserted between "AA" and "BB" to avoid "AAA" or "BBB"
  
  # Strategy:
  # 1. Use all "AB" strings, since they do not contribute to "AAA" or "BBB"
  # 2. Alternate "AA" and "BB" strings to maximize length, respecting the constraint
  # 3. If "AA" or "BB" are left without "AB", limit their use to 2
  
  # The maximum number of "AA" or "BB" we can use directly is twice the number of each plus "AB"
  max_aa_bb_use = [x, y].min + z
  
  # If we have more "AA" or "BB" than the other, calculate the extra
  extra = (x - max_aa_bb_use).abs + (y - max_aa_bb_use).abs
  
  # We can use an extra "AA" or "BB" only if there are "AB" strings to separate them
  # Otherwise, we are limited by the count of the lesser of "AA" or "BB" plus "AB"
  if extra > 0 && z > 0
    extra_use = [extra, z].min
  else
    extra_use = 0
  end
  
  # Calculate the maximum length
  # Each "AA", "BB", and "AB" contribute 2 to the length
  # Extra "AA" or "BB" can be used up to the limit determined by "AB"
  max_length = 2 * (max_aa_bb_use + z + extra_use)
  
  max_length
end
